page.title: 07CARLTON NATURE RESERVE
page.content: {Carlton Nature Reserve}was established in 1976 by local volunteers and Barnsley Borough Council who owned the land. Mining subsidence made Shaw Dike flood the area to make the marshland. The Reserve has forty acres and is four feet deep in the middle; the area has{marshland and both dry and damp {grassland.}The damp grassland to the south has lots of{wild flowers;}the dry grassland, also to the south, has mostly been destroyed by farming. The rarest visitors are the{Dartford {Warbler}and the{Alpine Swift;}over 50 species of bird, including{Coot, {Moorhen, Mallard}have been seen. 3000 birds have been ringed since 1976. Many problems are caused by vandals who rip down fences and raid nests as well as the smoke and noise from the nearby{scrapyards.}The Wardens say "The more damage, the less Nature."
